author: creemeeseason
body:
I've been eyeing ADI (analog devices) or TXN (Texas instruments). They make analog chips instead of digital and have a virtual duopoly. Analog chips have a long life cycle, sometimes 10 years plus, so these companies aren't in a constant technology cycle race. As a result they basically mint money off existing tech. 

Not as glamorous, but their chops go into everything. 5g, cars, phones, satellites, industry... basically all growing fields.

author: Summebride
body: Autodesk is nice, but I always prefer Adobe in that category.  Autodesk is needed by very niche companies and departments.  But Adobe software is needed by basically everyone.  Market is way more broad.

author: JonskMusic
body:
Exactly. I don't get it. I mean... photoshop is/was ubiquitous but. its pricey for people. There are people who want to make content and can't afford 50 a month for Premiere etc. Also Adobe has been teasing some really cool AI stuff for years.... but where is it? They haven't really done anything huge in a while.. Creative Cloud is okay.. but its clunky and people don't like paying subscription and they don't like dealing with millions of passwords on an enterprise level etc. Adobe could be great.. but they need to do something big.... although every lawyer on the planet uses Acrobat and calls it Adobe. "Do you have adobe?"... Yet acrobat itself is kind of clunky as well.   


But who is their rival? If you look it up.. None of those companies have much to do with creating content: "Adobe's top competitors include SAP, Salesforce, DocuSign, Dropbox, Getty Images, Shutterstock, Apple, Microsoft, IBM and Autodesk. Adobe is a software company developing digital marketing and media solutions."

author: DontUseEris
body:
Neither is for assemblage. The CAD (assemblage software) is either SolidWorks  or AutoDesk. 

Chegg has the answers to a lot of the questions in the textbooks it also has 24/7 tutoring. 

Wolfram Alpha can answer almost any math question. If you are willing to go pro, I will show you how it got the answer.

author: 10xwannabe
body:
Okay guess you are not invested then?  :)  

Not to start a debate, but I would be careful sitting on your high horse looking down on all of us before you look at yourself.  If you do any broad based index fund investing then you are undoubtedly invested in tobacco and alcohol companies.  Tobacco is linked to the 5 leading causes of death in America (likely same in Canada).  Alcohol is related to 50% of all fatal car accidents in America (likely same in Canada).  If you wear sneakers or any type of clothing you would be surprised what type of at best adult and at worst child sweat shops they are made from in third-third world companies. If you like green energy you would be surprised at how much oil is needed to make green energy products.

Trust me NO ONE really can stand on a pedestal in this day in age.  Just matters what you accept and what you choose to not be cognizant of in your daily life.  Running a google search itself consumes energy (carbon footprint).  I doubt you are outside planting trees to make up for it.    

BTW, sticking to this discussion.  How many water wells has Disney (part owner) and Nat Geo dug or paid for in Namibia vs. RECAF?  RECAF cares about making money, but as far as I know they have done more for the Namibian people then Nat Geo does/has despite the latter making millions of their story to sell articles. 

The problem with the green folks is they are ALWAYS hypocritical.  How did those journalist get to Namibia to do the article?  They flew.  Did they plant trees or pay for conversion of methane gases in landfills to make their flights carbon neutral?  Nope.  

Just keep in mind the old adage if you point one finger at someone there are 3 pointing right back at you.

author: LaOnionLaUnion
body: I think it’s going to be a major player in ML/AI coupled with its products. As a developer, their play with arm chips seems huge. Having a development machine that runs arm natively and which is already popular with developers is probably a bigger step than most people are cognizant of. It’s hardly a home run at this point but it reminds me that they are still making big Silicon Valley style plays and thinking big picture.

author: ElCalvo069
body:
You have 7 months to go so that's 2 earnings reports and potentially some holiday sales info. If your analysis leads you to believe that you'll be ITM then wait it out. 

Just be cognizant of time decay (theta) which accelerates the closer you get to expiry and eats into the value of the option.

And like others mentioned - have an exit plan before executing the trade.

author: juan62389
body:
CORNING, N.Y., June 03, 2021 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Corning Incorporated (NYSE:GLW) today introduced its latest innovation, Corning SMF-28® Contour optical fiber, to help telecommunications operators address the ever-expanding number of connected devices, build-out of 5G networks, and advances in cloud computing.​
Networks perform at their best when errors are minimized during fiber installation and when existing infrastructure is used efficiently during upgrades. Corning engineered SMF-28 Contour fiber to meet those needs. This groundbreaking product will allow customers to seamlessly upgrade their optical infrastructures, enabling the cost-effective deployment of future-ready networks. The fiber offers:

author: salfkvoje
body:
If you were confident that a lot of people will have suddenly more complicated taxes in 2022, what would you think about H&R Block ($HRB) or Intuit ($INTU)

Intuit looks pretty damn good, from pretty much any time interval. That's probably a good sign, but as a newish investor, I'm also wondering if there's a perspective where they have less room to grow than H&R Block. 

Though also, H&R has been around forever, and the history of the price action doesn't look promising. Any insights on valuing these two companies?

author: pdieff
body:
UPST…. $50-$70 by SEP

Which of you fools think UPST will pump again after lockup expiration. Allow me to pop your cherry and encourage any of you to proof me wrong. 

1. 60% plus of their loans are approved and financed by 1 shady ass bank (Cross River Bank) which also finances most of the loans for shitty fintech companies like Affirm & CoinBase. 

2. 65% of their referrals also come form one company (Intuit - INTU) via their Credit Karma platform. At any point INTU can decide to go in to lending and destroy little UPST. 

3. 20% of UPST is owned by one hedge fund (Third Point) they invested in UPST back in 2005 and they also own a large chunk of Sentinel One which is going public in the next month.  So if you think they won’t sell think twice.  Also with 20% ownership and only 50% of the outstanding shares able to trade prior to lockup well now you know how they drive to price so high.  

4. Lastly it trades at 45X Sales in 2020 that shit was allowed in 2021 the market is gonna smell blood and decimate them.

author: ryry1237
body:
>  if you invest in a company at its peak

I thought INTU was at its peak when it hit $400. Now it's at $472.

I thought NVDA was at its peak when it hit $600. Now it's at $713.

I thought MSFT was at its peak when it hit $200. Now it's at $257.

I thought GOOG was at its peak when it hit $1,700. Now it's at $2513 (I really missed the boat on this one).

Calling the peaks is not nearly as easy as you think it is.

author: OneofOneViper
body: Actually the quality of loans exceeds all other lenders in the US.  The reason for this is that they are a fintech company.  They have contracts with other companies like Intuit, Schwab, etc...  They buy information for advertisement purposes, and then advertise to the type of consumer that would create a good loan candidate with the lowest risk.

body: Actually, even if you dont get a refund, all the major players auto debit your bank account after X number of days, 36 for Intuit/Turbotax for example. Turbotax smashed earnings this year, so unless you think it was all from stealing HR customers I would not.

author: ExistentialCricket
body:
Has anyone here ever heard of or invested with MasterWorks?

It's a brokerage for investing in fine art that boasts 20% returns or more compared to the usual suspects. I have read about how fine art is kind of like the wild west because who can really say how much art is worth or appreciates and many people launder money through art. But that makes me think, is this a recession proof option? Intuit (turbo tax/quickbooks) was pushing it as an offer on their site so it must be somewhat reputable I would think.

Curious of any one else's take.
